asset.name: IBSRELA
asset.one_liner: First-in-class NHE3 inhibitor for IBS-C — 92% YoY revenue growth, on track for >$1B peak

target.name: NHE3
target.pathway: Intestinal sodium absorption → fluid balance and phosphate-mediated visceral pain signaling

biology.simple_explanation: NHE3 is the major sodium-absorbing transporter on the apical membrane of intestinal epithelial cells. It is responsible for absorbing the majority of ingested sodium from the GI tract. Inhibiting NHE3 reduces sodium (and consequently water) absorption, increasing fluid in the intestinal lumen. Additionally, NHE3 inhibition reduces intestinal phosphate absorption, which through a TRPV1-mediated mechanism reduces visceral pain signaling.
biology.pathway_detail: NHE3 sits on the brush border of enterocytes and exchanges luminal Na+ for intracellular H+. Blocking NHE3 retains sodium and water in the lumen, accelerating transit. Separately, reduced phosphate absorption lowers tight junction permeability and attenuates TRPV1-mediated visceral afferent firing, reducing abdominal pain.
downstream_effects: Increased intestinal fluid secretion and accelerated transit
Addresses both constipation AND abdominal pain in IBS-C
Reduced intestinal phosphate absorption (basis for XPHOZAH indication)

why_good_target.clinical_validation: IBSRELA (tenapanor) FDA-approved for IBS-C; XPHOZAH (tenapanor) FDA-approved for hyperphosphatemia. Same target validated across two distinct indications.
why_good_target.unmet_need: 77% of patients on prescription IBS-C treatment (secretagogues) continue to experience residual abdominal and stool-related symptoms [Corp '25 S6]

why_previous_approaches_incomplete.challenge: Existing IBS-C therapies (secretagogues like linaclotide, plecanatide, lubiprostone) work by stimulating fluid secretion via guanylate cyclase-C or chloride channels, but 77% of patients on these treatments continue to experience residual symptoms
why_previous_approaches_incomplete.secretagogue_limitation: Secretagogues only address the constipation component — they stimulate fluid secretion but do not directly address abdominal pain through a distinct mechanism
why_previous_approaches_incomplete.nhe3_solution: NHE3 inhibition works through a fundamentally different pathway — targeting absorption rather than secretion — and has a dual mechanism that addresses both constipation AND pain

mechanism.type: Small molecule — locally acting NHE3 inhibitor
mechanism.how_it_works: IBSRELA inhibits NHE3 (sodium-hydrogen exchanger 3) on the apical surface of the intestinal epithelium. By blocking sodium absorption, it increases intestinal fluid secretion and accelerates transit, while also reducing visceral hypersensitivity through a phosphate-mediated mechanism. This addresses both the constipation AND the abdominal pain of IBS-C.
mechanism.why_this_approach: IBSRELA is NOT a secretagogue (unlike Linzess/linaclotide and Trulance/plecanatide which stimulate chloride/fluid secretion via guanylate cyclase-C). Different MOA means it works through a distinct pathway, providing an option for the 77% of IBS-C patients who still have residual symptoms on existing therapies.
mechanism.differentiation: Only non-secretagogue approved for IBS-C. Locally acting (minimally absorbed <1%), so minimal systemic exposure. Dual mechanism: addresses both constipation and abdominal pain.

locally_acting.advantage: Minimal systemic exposure reduces off-target effects
locally_acting.distribution: Acts locally in the GI tract

lead.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome with Constipation (IBS-C)
lead.patient_population: Millions of adults in the US
lead.current_penetration: Growing rapidly — 92% YoY TRx growth in Q3 2025
lead.rationale: Only non-secretagogue in a $4B+ market where 77% of patients remain symptomatic on existing therapies

indications.total_addressable_patients: Large — IBS-C affects millions of US adults
indications.development_strategy: Focused commercial execution in IBS-C with same molecule (tenapanor) also approved as XPHOZAH for hyperphosphatemia

market_opportunity.total_addressable_market: $4.0B U.S. IBS-C indicated net product sales in 2024 (+16% YoY) [Corp '25 S7]
market_opportunity.total_rxs: 6.3M U.S. TRxs in 2024 (+11% YoY) for IBS-C indicated products [Corp '25 S7]
market_opportunity.trx_growth: TRxs for IBS-C indicated products have grown 21% from 2020 to 2024 [Corp '25 S7]
market_opportunity.unmet_need: 77% of patients on prescription IBS-C treatment continue to experience residual symptoms [Corp '25 S6]
market_opportunity.competitive_advantage: Only non-secretagogue — different mechanism means additive market growth, not just share theft
market_opportunity.market_dynamic: No 'one-size-fits-all' treatment — need for multiple mechanisms drives expansion of IBSRELA market share alongside overall market growth [Corp '25 S7]

design.dosing: Tenapanor 50mg BID vs placebo for 26 weeks

overall_responder.what_it_measures: Proportion achieving both >=30% reduction in worst abdominal pain AND >=1 CSBM/week increase in >=6 of 12 weeks
overall_responder.regulatory_status: FDA primary endpoint for IBS-C approval

abdominal_pain_responder.what_it_measures: >=30% reduction in worst abdominal pain in >=6 of 12 weeks

csbm_weekly.full_name: Complete Spontaneous Bowel Movements per Week
csbm_weekly.what_it_measures: Weekly frequency of CSBMs over 26-week treatment period

results.tenapanor: Significantly improved vs placebo through Week 26

key_findings: Quick onset — relief from constipation, bloating, and pain typically within 1 week [Corp '25 S9]
Additional improvement in abdominal pain over first 3-4 months [Corp '25 S9]
Improvements maintained with continued use through end of 26-week trial [Corp '25 S9]

safety.summary: Most common adverse reactions (>=2% and > placebo) [Corp '25 S9]
key_findings: Diarrhea: 16% vs 4% placebo — most common AE, mechanism-related
safety.notes: Severe diarrhea reported in 2.5% of IBSRELA-treated patients. Diarrhea is mechanism-related (NHE3 inhibition increases intestinal fluid).

commercial_performance.description: IBSRELA revenue trajectory shows exceptional commercial execution

competitive_landscape.limitation: Secretagogue — 77% of patients still symptomatic; diarrhea AE; same-class as Trulance

differentiation.mechanism: IBSRELA targets sodium absorption (NHE3); Linzess stimulates fluid secretion (GC-C)
differentiation.positioning: Complementary not competitive — different MOA provides option for Linzess partial responders

competitive_landscape.threat_level: Low — different mechanism; market is growing for both

competitive_landscape.limitation: Same class as Linzess with limited differentiation; declining share

differentiation.mechanism: Same GC-C class; IBSRELA's NHE3 mechanism is fundamentally different

competitive_landscape.limitation: Nausea common; now generic; declining market share; secretagogue

differentiation.mechanism: Different mechanism; IBSRELA is newer with better tolerability profile

bull_case.point: Revenue trajectory is exceptional — 92% YoY growth in Q3 2025
bull_case.confidence: High — Multiple quarters of accelerating growth

bull_case.point: Only non-secretagogue in IBS-C gives durable differentiation
bull_case.evidence: 77% of patients on existing Rx still symptomatic; different MOA means complementary not competitive [Corp '25 S6]

bull_case.point: >$1B peak revenue achievable before Aug 2033 patent expiry
bull_case.evidence: Current run-rate ~$350M+ annualized and accelerating; 10+ years of growth runway [Corp '25 S10]
bull_case.confidence: Medium — Depends on sustained penetration growth

bear_case.point: Patent cliff in August 2033 limits total value capture
bear_case.evidence: Even at >$1B peak, only ~5 years of peak revenue before generic entry [Corp '25 S24]
bear_case.counter_argument: RDX10531 (next-gen NHE3 inhibitor) in development could extend franchise

bear_case.evidence: IBSRELA is only approved for IBS-C; no CIC indication (unlike Linzess)
bear_case.counter_argument: Focused strategy may actually drive deeper IBS-C penetration; XPHOZAH separately covers CKD
bear_case.probability: Low — focus is a feature not a bug

key_debates.question: Can IBSRELA sustain >50% annual growth through 2027?
key_debates.bull_view: Yes — still early penetration; 77% of patients unsatisfied with secretagogues; GI specialists increasingly prescribing
key_debates.bear_view: No — growth deceleration inevitable as comparisons get harder; Linzess franchise is dominant
key_debates.what_resolves_it: Quarterly TRx trends and FY2026 guidance

key_debates.question: Does differentiated MOA translate to durable market share?
key_debates.bull_view: Yes — structurally different mechanism means patients who fail secretagogues switch to IBSRELA
key_debates.bear_view: No — GI docs may not distinguish mechanisms in practice; payer pushback on non-preferred formulary
key_debates.what_resolves_it: NBRx share trends and payer coverage expansion

probability_of_success.note: Already approved and commercial — no clinical risk
probability_of_success.peak_sales_confidence: Medium — >$1B achievable but depends on sustained growth

catalysts.what_to_watch: Final FY2025 revenue vs $270-275M guidance; Q4 trajectory
Growth rate guidance; path to >$1B peak visibility
EU/ROW partnering for IBS-C; Canada performance [Corp '25 S23]

regulatory_path.label: Treatment of IBS-C in adults
regulatory_path.dosing: 50mg taken orally twice daily, immediately prior to breakfast or the first meal of the day, and immediately prior to dinner

key_slides.6: IBSRELA growth metrics and unmet need
